skill.name: simpy
skill.description: Process-based discrete-event simulation framework in Python. Use this skill when building simulations of systems with processes, queues, resources, and time-based events such as manufacturing systems, service operations, network traffic, logistics, or any system where entities interact with shared resources over time.

skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Scanned eight text files including scripts and reference guides. No credential access, network calls, or external command execution detected. Content matches simulation guidance and local monitoring utilities.

content.value_statement: You need to model queues, resources, and time based events without building infrastructure. This skill provides SimPy templates, monitoring utilities, and guidance to run and analyze simulations.
actual_capabilities: Provide a ready to run queue simulation template with configurable arrivals, resources, and run time.
Generate customer processes with exponential inter arrival times and normal service durations.
Collect wait time, service time, and throughput statistics with a built in report.
Monitor resource queue length and utilization over time with patched request and release tracking.
Export monitoring events to a CSV file for analysis.
limitations: Does not install SimPy or other dependencies.
Templates focus on basic queueing patterns rather than complex optimization.
No built in visualization or plotting output.
Real time execution guidance is documentation only.

use_cases.title: Assess staffing levels
use_cases.description: Model a service desk with limited agents and estimate average wait times under different arrival rates.

use_cases.title: Prototype system behavior
use_cases.description: Build a discrete event model to test resource contention and throughput before a real deployment.

use_cases.title: Teach queueing concepts
use_cases.description: Demonstrate how processes, events, and resources interact in a simple classroom simulation.

prompt_templates.title: Start a basic queue
prompt_templates.scenario: Beginner setup for a small queue
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a simple SimPy example with two servers and customers arriving every 3 time units. Summarize what the code does.

prompt_templates.title: Add monitoring
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the ResourceMonitor to track queue length and utilization for a single resource. Explain how to report results.

prompt_templates.title: Tune parameters
prompt_templates.prompt: Modify the basic simulation template to use arrival_rate 1.5 and service_time_mean 4.0. Explain expected effects.

prompt_templates.title: Export results
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to export resource monitoring data to CSV and list the columns that will be written.

output_examples.input: Simulate a two server queue for 50 time units and summarize key metrics.
output: Total customers served and average wait time
Average service time and throughput estimate
Notes on resource utilization trend over time

best_practices: Set a random seed for reproducible simulations.
Use context managers for resource requests to avoid leaks.
Collect statistics during the run, not only at the end.
anti_patterns: Using blocking Python calls inside processes.
Changing time units without updating parameters.

faq.question: Is this compatible with modern Python?
faq.answer: Yes. The examples target standard Python 3 and the SimPy API.

faq.question: What are the main limits?
faq.answer: It provides templates and monitoring, not full domain models or optimization solvers.

faq.question: Can I integrate this with my codebase?
faq.answer: Yes. Import the scripts and adapt the process functions and configuration.

faq.question: Does it access or send my data?
faq.answer: No. The scripts run locally and only write optional CSV outputs you request.

faq.question: What should I check if results look wrong?
faq.answer: Verify arrival and service parameters, resource capacity, and that processes yield events.

faq.question: How does this compare to general simulation tools?
faq.answer: It is focused on SimPy workflows, not a full simulation suite with GUIs or solvers.
